question.body: What are two general properties of hash functions?

answer.body: Compression (maps an input space of arbitrary finite length to an output of fixed length) and ease of computation.

question.body: What 3 properties constitute cryptographic hash functions?

answer.body: Pre-image resistance (impossible to find the original x if only h(x) is given), second pre-image resistance (impossible to find y (different from x) if x and h(x) are given s.t. h(x)==h(y)), collision resistance (impossible to find distinct x and y s.t. h(x)==h(y)).

question.body: What is an additionally beneficial (but not required) property of cryptographic hash functions?

answer.body: Hiding (impossible to determine x in h(r||x) given only the result of the hash)

question.body: Why are public keys of identities hashed before they are used as an address? Name two reasons and explain.

answer.body: Hashes are shorter and quantum computers can not break hash functions, preventing them from finding the private key.
